cards.english: (A watermark vertically on the right side reads: "Learn Kikuyu - Wĩrute Gĩkũyũ - Jĩfunze Kikuyu")** --- ### Examples * **(Nĩĩ) ndĩ na arata aingĩ** - (Me) I have many friends * **(Wee) wĩ na mũciari mwega** - You have a good parent * **(We) e na ngaari njerũ** - he/she has a new car (white car) * **(O) me na nyũmba nene** - They have a big house * **(Ithuĩ) twĩ na kĩeha** - we are sad (we have sadness) --- ### Note **Omit the pronoun in brackets and the sentence will still make sense in Kikuyu

cards.english: Kim Ole Kimanĩ** 1. **Kĩero**... **Thigh** 2. **Cĩerĩo**.... **Thighs** 3. **Wambũĩ mĩcore**....**Zebra** 4. **Ĩhoerõ**.... **Church** 5. **Ĩhererĩo**.... **Hell** **(Names listed in the image: Edu Njeru, Jeremy Ng'ang'a, Kim Ole Kimanĩ, George Fenzy, John Gathatwa)** (The watermark at the bottom reads: "Learn Kikuyu - Wĩrute Gĩkũyũ - Jĩfunze Kikuyu") *** ## 2. Transcription of image\_adf029.jpg (Verb: Aka) **(The text is set against a tan background, bordered by African-style animal prints.)** * **Wagatano - Friday** * **Verb - Aka** * **Aka** - **build** * **Gũaka** - **to build** * **Gũaka nyũmba** - **to build a house** * **Mwakĩre nyũmba** - **build for him/her ...** * **Aka** - **build**; **Akai** - **Build (you all)** * **Mwako** - **a building**; **(A watermark diagonally across the text reads: "Learn Kikuyu - Wĩrute Gĩkũyũ")
cards.cultural_notes: Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons by Emmanuel Kariuki. Native speaker vocabulary from Easy Kikuyu lessons
